results.title: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 1.
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia, Anthony Buckley and Robert Francis
results.brief_description: Episode 1: The Pioneers. 1894-1927. Australians of the 1890’s were among the first to discover the film medium, producing a dynamic band of film-makers with a bold and uncompromising vision. Raymond Longford, Lottie Lyall and Beau Smith fought against incredible odds and produced classics like “The Story of the Kelly Gang”, “Robbery under Arms”, “The Squatters Daughter” and the internationally acclaimed “The Sentimental Bloke.” Episode 2: “O.K. for Sound” 1928-1948. The new technology of talking pictures revolutionised the film industry and created new stars. “In the Wake of the Bounty” introduced Errol Flynn. This was the era of the Dad and Dave films and masterpieces such as Charles Chauvel’s “Forty Thousand Horseman.” Australia’s documentary tradition continued with classics like “Journey of a Nation” and “Kokoda Front Line.” Narrated by Bryan Brown.
results.title_for_label: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 1.

results.title: The Cellist
results.brief_description: Guy is returning to Australia when he is befriended by Les. We learn that Guy is a cellist with the London Philharmonic, coming home to see his daughter. However, when the daughter fails to meet him, Guy is taken home to stay with Les’s family. He gets to know Lorraine… Cast: Guy Roper - Rhys McConnachie Lorraine - Tracey Higginson Les Batson - John Clayton with a cameo appearance by James Morrison as the trumpet cyclist.

results.title: The Cell: a functioning structure. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: CRM Educational Films and Steven Katten
results.brief_description: Uses cinemicroscopy and animation to show chemical events which take place within the living cell. Describes genetic code and DNA and the role of RNA. Also discusses the chloroplast of the plant cell and investigates cellular communications. Features Dr Donald Fosket. Hosted and narrated by Dr David Suzuki.

results.title: The Cell: a functioning structure. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: CRM Educational Films and Steven Katten
results.brief_description: Uses cinemicroscopy and special-effects animation to present the cell as a functioning entity as well as a stable, reproducible structure. The key functions of DNA and protein enzymes are revealed along with the way cells obtain nourishment and includes a discussion on cellular reproduction and cell structure. Narrated and hosted by Dr David Suzuki.

results.title: The Cell [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Radical Media, Julio Caro, Eric McLeod and Tarsem Singh
results.brief_description: Catherine Deane, a gifted psychotherapist, partakes in a new treatment that takes her inside the minds of catatonic patients, aiming to heal their emotional trauma. Whilst working on a comatose child, Deane is asked to enter into the mind of an unconscious serial killer in order to determine the whereabouts of his latest victim. Once inside Deane finds herself trapped there and a FBI agent is sent in to retrieve her. Much screen time is devoted to the scenarios that unfurl inside the psychopath’s mind - extensive and elaborate settings that feature the murderer, (as adult and child), Deane and the FBI agent interacting in various guises. A psychological thriller, “The Cell” mimics the gory excesses of films such as “Seven” and “Silence of the lambs”, following their patterning of gruesome depictions of (typically female) detestable and sadistic murder. Tarsem Singh’s debut feature is principally a visual feast of stylish extravagance that establishes his penchant for intricate set-ups, heavily reliant on computer generated graphics and blue screen technology to deliver the vision.

results.title: The Cell
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Jim Stephenson
results.brief_description: Shows chemical events which take place within the living cell. Presents the various protein functions, including D.N.A. and genetic coding, discusses mitochondrian and chloroplasts, and investigates cellular communication.

results.title: The Ceiling of the Sistine Chapel
results.brief_description: A study of the Michelangelo paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican. At the beginning of the sixteenth century, Bramante drew the plans for the new Basilica of St. Peter. Raphael peopled the halls in the Vatican with figures and stories of ideal beauty and Michelangelo displayed on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel that history of mankind which bears witness to the superhuman task of a superhuman spirit.

results.title: The Cavity caper
results.creator_credit: Newfilms and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A dramatisation for children on the subject of dental care, in which Big Al and Louis try to outwit Kev Casual, but the Tooth Fairy comes to the rescue. The Army is also brought into the fight against plaque No other credits available. Cast includes Colin Friels. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: The Cave community
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Explains why the relatively unchanging environment of caves provides biologists with important data. Shows the evolutionary and adaptive modifications of cave dwelling bats, fish, insects and salamanders.

results.title: The Cattle story
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Northern Australian export beef industry. Historical survey shows introduction of beef cattle to Australia by Governor Phillip. Gives detailed account of beef-raising areas, stock routes and mustering procedures, and indicates importance of the industry in Australia’s economy. Adoption of modern transport methods, in particular, has done much to raise the quality of Australian beef. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
